title: Quiz 2 - Reading Comprehension
instruction: Read the following passage carefully and answer the questions given below them. Certain words/phrases have been printed in bold to help you locate them while answering some of the questions. After Singapore gained nationhood in 1965, Lee Kuan Yew is said to have held Kolkata up as a role model for the new city-state. It is likely an apocryphal story, but telling for all of that. Even in its decline, the former first city of India could plausibly be considered worthy of emulation by a leader who would go on to become the high priest of the Asian tiger economies. Lee’s fancy, presumably, didn’t last very long once Kolkata’s rot truly set in. Over the course of a few decades, India’s economic nerve centre of two centuries’ standing would fade into near irrelevance. Is there a lesson here for its successor, Mumbai? The Mumbai Development Plan (MDP) 2034, unveiled last week, aims at building on the city’s economic pre-eminence over the next two decades. It is a mixed bag from an urban planning perspective. But it also feeds into larger questions about Mumbai’s trajectory. Mumbai is currently in the midst of its second economic cycle. The first cycle began in the mid-19th century with two global developments: the American Civil War that caused cotton prices to spike internationally and the construction of the Suez Canal. The first played to Mumbai’s industrial strength and the second to its being a strategically located port city. The cycle lasted for a century, ending with the collapse of the city’s textile mill heartland in the early 1980s. This triggered a shift in Mumbai’s economic paradigm. A manufacturing exodus led to a secondary sector decline. The tertiary sector stepped into the breach, particularly after liberalization. The MDP is based on the assumption that the second cycle will continue as it has. It projects that the primary sector’s share of Mumbai’s gross domestic product will decline from 31% currently to 20% by 2034. Concurrently, the tertiary sector’s share will rise from 68% to 80%. It seems like a safe assumption on the face of it. But it falls prey to what historian and urban expert Lewis Mumford termed the fallacy of the first attitude—the assumption that past trend lines will continue indefinitely. This thinking was partly responsible for the urban detritus of the former mills that is central Mumbai today. Mumbai’s leaders should take note as the city’s reliance on financial services grows, with manufacturing continuing to move to neighbouring districts like Thane and Pune. A healthy economic future as a financial nerve centre is certainly viable. But it is no coincidence that New York, London, Hong Kong and Shanghai—leading financial hubs, all—are also now start-up and tech hubs. The barriers between the two industries are increasingly permeable. The latter is both disrupting and enabling the former. Mumbai is poorly placed for such cross-pollination. The distorted real estate market and lack of a deep talent pool have led to it ceding ground to Bengaluru, Hyderabad and New Delhi. Early stage funding is still relatively healthy—but growth capital and achieving scale are increasingly less so. Is it possible for Mumbai to continue to grow as a financial hub over the next two decades, as it has thus far, without branching out? Perhaps. But it’s far from a safe bet—especially in light of potential rivals such as the Gujarat International Finance Tec-City, a planned smart city and international financial services centre. The increasing reliance on the tertiary sector poses sociopolitical questions as well. Mumbai’s textile mill workers were among the best paid industrial workers in India. Marathi workers dominated this workforce; it also gave low-skilled migrants an opportunity to enter the formal labour force. It’s no coincidence that parochial politics gained ground in Mumbai with the decline of the secondary sector and the rise of a tertiary sector that required higher skilled workers. Nativist politics has an upfront economic cost, of course. But they also have a more insidious effect. In an influential 1903 essay, The Metropolis And Modern Life, German sociologist Georg Simmel wrote that the metropolis’ indifference to difference—its elevation of the individual over group identity—allowed more space for economic rationalism. The reverse, obviously, holds true as well. That is worth bearing in mind when considering Mumbai’s economic future. It would take a brave man to predict Mumbai’s decline. It pays 60% of the country’s customs duty collections and 40% of income tax to the national exchequer—although the latter is perhaps misleading given that it hosts a large chunk of the country’s largest companies and the tax figures are not indicative of economic activity. More broadly, it had few rivals until recently; closing that gap will not be easy. But its continued dominance is not inevitable; another financial hub, New York, learnt that lesson in the 1970s. The infrastructure and housing problems the MDP addresses are important. But the solutions must be allied to a larger vision of the city’s future.

quiz.text: Walmart investment is marked as a big boost to middle- class Indian market. Justify. (I) India is now on its way to become world’s largest consumption class. (II) With Walmart investment, startup business will get validation. (III) Indian market endured a slow growth since long.
options: Only (I)
Only (II)
Both (I) and (II)
Both (II) and (III)
All are correct

quiz.text: According to the passage, why government is willing to invest in retail sector?
options: As retail sector is the sector which is accessed by large population.
As government is planning to shut down all the small stores.
As retail sector is the most progressing sector that gives the GDP a substantial rise.
As retail sector provides largest number of jobs to skilled and unskilled people.
Both (b) and (d)

quiz.text: According to the passage, the step(s) government should take in order to make e- commerce flourish in India is/are:
options: Improve internet connection to make e-commerce easily accessible to all.
Hire people thus preventing unemployment situation.
make delivery mechanism able to tackle infrastructure and warehousing problems.
Emphasize on large scale real financial inclusion.
All are correct

quiz.text: The Flipkart-Walmart deal is a great step forward for the development of the retail sector in India. How? (I) It uplifts the e-commerce business in India. (II) It creates better opportunity for youth to explore their talent. (III) It generates employment for both skilled and semi- skilled labour force.
options: Only (I)
Only (II)
Both (I) and (III)
Both (II) and (III)
All are correct

quiz.text: The challenge(s) that India is facing in retail sector is/ are:
options: People are sceptical about banking transactions
Inefficient cash on delivery transactions
Poor internet connectivity
Confined to big cities only
All

quiz.text: The appropriate title of the passage is
options: Sensing intense competition
The potential of Indian e-commerce
The Walmart- Flipkart deal
Consequences of demonetisation
Flipkart investment

quiz.text: Which of the following alternatives among the given five provides the most similar meaning(s) of the word given in BOLD as used in the passage? Fillip (I) encouragement (II) spur (III) boost (IV) Impetus
options: only (I)
only (I) and (III)
only (II) and (IV)
only (I), (III) and (IV)
all

quiz.text: Which of the following alternatives among the given five provides the most similar meaning(s) of the word given in BOLD as used in the passage? Slump (I) Stagflation (II) protrusion (III) Stagnation (IV) recession
options: only (I)
only (I) and (III)
only (II) and (IV)
only (I) and (IV)
all

quiz.text: Which of the following alternatives among the given five provides the most opposite meaning(s) of the word given in BOLD as used in the passage? Shackles (I) detritus (II) behest (III) rot (IV) vaunt
options: only (III)
only (II) and (III)
only (I) and (IV)
only (II), (III) and (IV)
None of these

quiz.text: Which of the following alternatives among the given five provides the most opposite meaning(s) of the word given in BOLD as used in the passage? Weary (I) augur (II) zealous (III) enthusiastic (IV) nefarious
options: only (III)
only (II) and (III)
only (I) and (IV)
only (II), (III) and (IV)
None of these

quiz.text: What does the author mean by the phrase “It is likely an apocryphal story” in the context of the passage?
options: The story seems to be illusory as Kolkata is never taken up as a role model by Singapore.
Lee Kuan Yew gave the story an unending conclusion by considering Kolkata as the role model.
The story is an axiom as Kolkata is well established at that time when it is considered as a role model by Lee Kuan Yew.
It seems doubtful that Kolkata even in its tumbling situation would be considered as a role model.
The story, irrespective of its authenticity, as made by Lee Kuan Yew is only to make Singapore advanced.

quiz.text: What was/ were the outcome(s) of economic cycle that began in mid- 19th century in Mumbai? (I) Decline in secondary and tertiary sector. (II) Improvement in the industrial strength of Mumbai. (III) A sharp decrease in the cotton prices internationally. (IV) Collapse of the city’s textile mill.
options: Only (I) is correct
Both (II) and (IV) are correct
Only (I), (II) and (III) are correct
Only (II), (III) and (IV) are correct
All are correct

quiz.text: According to the passage, what problem does Mumbai face?
options: The pace of growth capital is not as expected.
Contorted coordination between all leading financial hubs and start- ups.
Lack of allocation of funds.
Both (a) and (b)
All are correct

quiz.text: “It had few rivals until recently; closing that gap will not be easy”. Which gap does the author talk about? (I) The gap between urban and rural development (II) The gap between Marathi workers and other workers (III) The gap between secondary and tertiary sector
options: Only (I) is correct
Only (II) is correct
Only (I) and (II) are correct
Only (II) and (III) are correct
All are correct

quiz.text: The appropriate title of the passage is
options: Mapping Mumbai’s future: the big questions
A step towards The Mumbai Development Plan (MDP) 2034
Liberalization of sociopolitical issues
The rise of tertiary sector
The infrastructure and housing problems

quiz.text: The Mumbai development plan aims to
options: develop the sociopolitical reconciliation.
address the infrastructure issues.
improve the economic condition of Mumbai.
Both (b) and (c)
All are correct

quiz.text: Which of the following alternatives among the five options provides the most similar meaning(s) of the word given in BOLD as used in the passage? Insidious (I) preclude (II) instigate (III) sneaky (IV) impetus
options: Only (III)
Only (II) and (IV)
Only (I), (II) and (III)
Only (II), (III) and (IV)
All of the above

quiz.text: Which of the following alternatives among the five options provides the most similar meaning(s) of the word given in BOLD as used in the passage? Detritus (I) spur (II) dregs (III) consent (IV) wreckage
options: Only (III)
Only (II) and (IV)
Only (I), (II) and (III)
Only (II), (III) and (IV)
All of the above

quiz.text: Which of the following alternatives among the five options provides the most opposite meaning(s) of the word given in BOLD as used in the passage? Ceding (I) attaining (II) concurring (III) sanctioning (IV) Acquiring
options: Only (III)
Only (I) and (IV)
Only (I), (II) and (III)
Only (II), (III) and (IV)
All are correct

quiz.text: Which of the following alternatives among the five options provides the most opposite meaning(s) of the word given in BOLD as used in the passage? Inevitable (I) avoidable (II) alleviate (III) uncertain (IV) concede
options: Only (I)
Only (II)
Only (I) and (III)
Only (II), (III) and (IV)
All are correct
